div.p: Greetings. Today, early in the morning, I received your letter, honorable compater, and I thank you continuously for communicating everything to us so faithfully. Now I cannot write much, because I am not yet completely certain about the matters I could write about, and this messenger is in a hurry to leave, who might bring to your council what I was otherwise going to write. If you learn anything certain from faithful friends there, please let me know through this same messenger. There is only one thing that I earnestly ask of you, and I am prompted by some friends to do so, to inform me about what is happening among the people of Glarus.

It is reported here that in some of their churches, idols, where they still remained, have been cast out, and from this, I do not know what danger might be threatening them from their neighbors. I have high hopes for the people of Valais.
But I cannot write more, I am forced to close the letter due to the messenger's hurried departure. Farewell.
Bern, August 12, almost the first hour after noon. Your Johannes Haller.
To the most distinguished man, Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the church of ZÃ¼rich, his dear lord and compater.
